OzhRQNvMWz1baN5GWBUkQA.text: We arrived as a family on a hot day a last week.  We stood by the bar on the first floor.  No one acknowledged us.  We had a group of four.  Then, when we ordered, we were told that the beer was not available because it was too hot.  After I told them they had just pulled about seven pints, in a row, they repeated that it was unavailable.  This is a tavern!  They sold us hard cider in bottles.  After sitting on the patio, a family with a newborn sat near us.  After fifteen minutes, the father's order included a pulled pint of beer.  We mentioned it to our server.  She was appalled.  She went to see if we could get a cold beer.  She never returned.  No explanation ever.  We were charged 12.5% service charge even though we ordered at the Bar and set our own table.  The Thames was lovely.  The service, not so.  The food was middling.  The expensive steak sandwich was overdone and grey.  Not again.  Too bad the Cutty Sark was closed.  It was probably the best competition for a Tavern that rests on its laurels from Rick Steves' recommendations.

SBvKNISuqW5IwfgE2-jgdg.text: this pub seems to be very popular to high out for weddings, it seems every time i have been there, a wedding has been taking place. it has lovely views of the river, and is on the door step of Greenwich just round the corner of the park and the cuttysark. this pub is very expensive though for what you get, and it does get very busy outside on a sunny afternoon. you can sit by the water, and really chill though if u do get a seat which i have to say are not that comfy. This pub does have loads of character, but that is just something I really don't look for in a pub.

EEhCjahbnMovemvXlI2HDQ.text: I've been here before for a drink and it's a lovely pub right on the river in Greenwich. But what I hadn't seen until last month is what a fantastic venue it is upstairs. I went to a wedding here and not only could the room accommodate the wedding ceremony itself but we were ushered into a lovely bar next to it with balconies overlooking the river, fed very good nibbles and kept well watered by the staff whilst the room was transformed for dining. The meal itself was surprisingly good considering the number of people to feed and the staff were very friendly. If you're looking for a decent sized wedding venue in London then I would definitely check this out.

bQuvGdS6nPI6HWWnjU6LRg.text: Great view and plenty of character (and wood) are what stick in my mind about this pub. The food was expensive but the range of real ales was good.

48uNxBjw7bQiXwwnJgek0g.text: Beware, I don't know if it's the pub's policy or individual waiters, but they try to charge for extra drinks. Ask for the recept and check. Shame really, because it's in a very nice location.

f54xU_kl5z_nTcybm10Dqg.text: Our friends took us here for drinks before dinner,  we would never find this place otherwise. The view was spectacular and I imagine it's even nicer in the summer. Can't comment much about anything else, we had one round of drinks and it was just fine.

KOg06fSf-siPXFQjZvtv3w.text: The place is quite magic. The view --to the Thames river and Canary Wharf-- is incomparable and it works great for a casual lunch or a romantic and glamorous dinner. Food is good, and it's best know for its typical white bait. Make sure you tip the waiters in cash, because they do not receive the tip left on credit cards!

qKIq-qiX1zd0gISOqxEPew.text: I can't properly rate this establishment as I did not eat here. But on a hot summer day I stopped in for a pint and sat at one of their tables overlooking the river which was absolute heaven. The decor felt like a real, old world pub, not some mass produced Fuller's beer pubs that pop up like McDonald's, so that in itself was a real treat. The staff were friendly and the selection of beer was quite good, including 2 choices for cider which is rare these days.

Veoi9R7mlwAzLJ9vhlb5rA.text: Good place on the river for a drink with a view, but good luck getting a seat outside in the warmer weather when there is a whole sprawl of people out there. This is a popular pub. The inside is nice enough though. The window seats have a great almost river level view of the thames (coming soon to an ever warming planet near youSouth London's underwater bar The Trafalgarenjoy a pint of your favourite ale while watching used condoms and dead fish glide by), but it is not all about the exterior viewthey have done a lovely job on the grand interior. Beer wise they have a large selection of lagers and 3 ales were on, a couple from Sharp's of Cornwall and one from Flowers. The sharp's own was alright.

uAJnhhl8cby-QHOf59RT2w.text: This is definitely my favorite place in Greenwich at night. If you go in a summer day, sitting outside the bar, with some wine and good company, trust me it's a great place. Lovely view of the Canary Wharf at night, and also it's good walk down the river Thames, next to the Maritime Museum.

Z78jcatlur12TO7tZug1Dg.text: Went here for a nice Saturday night with friends meeting up for drinks and a bit of food. Had an overall great experience, got a table by the window (they are premium, get here early if you want a good spot to sit). The service was excellent, just turn up at the bar and within seconds someone asks you what you want to order even when the place was busy. They have a good selection of beers on tap too... So, now you think, why did he only score it 3, well its the food. The menu has some tasty options but are a bit pricey (for a pub). I scrolled down the bar snack menu and I decided to go for the "Char-grilled chicken sandwich - with tomato relish, garlic mayo & chips" at a whopping 10 quid (a sandwich in the most posh pub perhaps would cost 10-12, but in a place like this I would expect 7-9 tops). Though, I thought the price would give me something to remember, though what was delivered was more something that would give me nightmares. The sandwich was delivered fast. Nice, though too fast for the chicken to been prepared on a grill, more like a microwave oven, then it was in a hamburger bun (really cheap one), once slice of lettuce, a kind of mayo-relish that had been squeezed out of something you buy in the supermarket and then, the best on the plate, a kind of coleslaw that actually seemed to been done in the kitchen and it was actually quite nice. Now, I was in between 2 and a 3, but in the end I scored the whole experience a 3 as the friendly staff, the environment (a really nice pub) and overall a great venue. Also, I know they have a restaurant too, though if it was the same kitchen that shipped out the disaster I got in front of me then I wouldn't even consider trying the restaurant. My friends foods (hamburgers, fish etc was a bit of a hit and miss too I think, but I give it up to them to review). Anyway, long story short, go here for drinks and a good pub experience, but stay away from anything that the kitchen dish out.

Kfu97hZCdOqwTwDb2wo8LQ.text: I was lucky enough to have a friend show me this place cuz I dunno how else I would've found it!We came here on a Friday night and ended up having one hell of a time. Trafalgar Tavern's prime, riverside location & view of the twinkling city lights is really to their advantage. We sipped on a few bottles of their white house wine at one of their outdoor tables by the river. Wine was just ok (it was house, so I wasn't surprised), but the Steak Baguette (Sirloin steak, caramelized onions, watercress w/ horseradish on a warm baguette w/ fat chips) that I had was scruuumtious! I had ordered it from the bar menu, but it definitely wasn't of bar food quality. Also, the chips were the best chips I've ever had. Way to do London justice.I noticed that others noted Trafalgar Tavern was dead when they visited, but when I went, the patio & riverside seating was packed. The interior was definitely not as poppin' given that it was a gorgeous, warm night out. All in all, Trafalgar Tavern set the scene for a memorable evening out!

auzaLaZ30f_Z7by4MROa3A.text: Again showing a lack of understanding of pubs, inc have made this quintessential old school river side boozer light and airy with touches of minimalism just to emphasise that they just don't 'get it'. Where this place needs vintage and character they have given it..well a touch of lKEA. Nice river views outside on the cramped up seating. Wine expensive and underwhelming

g3tTigWflD8wf6rrItdpqA.text: Pub with a great view and nice food as you're strolling around Greenwich. The roast is tasty and massive but a bit pricey (I don't think a roast should ever be above 10 quid unless it's really gonna knock your socks off). The ribs fall of the bone and have a lovely sauce on them. And Ploughman's is substantial but the bread it comes with isn't great.

EERwUJfMi1rjaIqcWJOitA.text: The Trafalgar is hidden away behind Greenwich University and is situated next to the Thames. The thing that drove me and my friends to it was the outdoor seating on the riverside which made for a very pleasant summers evening relaxing and watching the boats go by and looking over at the docklands. The only downside to using the outdoor facilities is that you have to let them know at the bar which then means you have to drink from plastic pint glasses, similar to those you would get at a football ground. Whilst the reason for this is obvious, it did feel like we were being robbed of an important aspect of a pub experience. Inside is beautiful, you can tell that the place has a history from the paintings, the layout and the high ceilings. I particular like that you can sit by the window and, in a similar way to when outside, view the Thames and city. However there are only a small handful of seats in which this is possible to be quick and grab them whilst you can. Drinking at the Trafalgar almost seems like a unique experience. The summer outside is a must for anyone in the Greenwich area.

qOSlIWhzS6iKdYHGP5uxAA.text: This establishment is a little off the beaten path and claims Charles Dickens as a patron. I suspect Charlie would have been a member of Yelp and quite active (especially in the Nightlife category) were he alive today. It was mid afternoon and the place was relatively empty when I stumbled in. I spent an enjoyable couple of hours chatting with the bartender and the couple of other patrons. I had trouble understanding their accents (as they did with my thick "Shekawgo" accent) but we figured out when to laugh at the punch lines in each others jokes.This capped off an enjoyable day of taking the tour boat here and the observatory. I took the train back and was pleased with myself for how long my bladder held out between bathrooms after leaving this place.

OnN-R-KFm-8PKhI40i2e4g.text: It's a great place to have a Sunday roast with a selection of chicken, pork or lamb; the roasted vegetables are incredible. Price range format roast is £15, but with the views and the ambience it's all worth it. Go early on a Sunday as it can be very busy.

G6wJvFf807ra7QfQlo21Ww.text: Here is a suggestion for a great day trip. Get on the Ferry from Westminster towards Greenwich. It will take 30 to 40 minutes. Once you arrive there have a walk around the lovely shops, cafes and markets. Then walk towards the Royal Observatory, its a steep walk but worth the view. Head down and take a look at the Maritime Museum, The University and to end this day trip head to this pub. It has been here for so long, has seen so many historic events and some crazy times that it's legendary. Don't miss the beautiful fire place, it has so much detail work. I didn't eat there but the food looks great. The vibe of the place is laid back and relaxed, what an excellent way to end a great day.

photos.caption: Photo of Trafalgar Tavern - London, United Kingdom

xMv8KVp6FSfDDOzge_yu4w.text: It's not the best pub in Greenwich. It's certainly not the worst. You get these good things: BBQ in summerGreat view of the riverBit of history - That Charles Dickens bloke used to write here. You'll get these bad things: Huge queues to the bar.Bloody expensive drinks when you get there.Not wonderful happy staff. I've never eaten here, but the restaurant looks nice. To be honest, i'd rather be in The Cutty Sark Tavern which is five minutes down the road.

r9FT7N2f6uTBipUokTp-ug.text: Whenever I come upon this pub I always get the impression that it would be suited to some Animal House style American frat party. Drunken rabbles hanging from the railings, loo rolls covering the place, fireworks launching from the windows. Alas the tainted babylon of my imaginings has yet to see fruition but this does make a well located stop off on the pub tour of Greenwich. At one point they were serving a savage ale called Nelson's Blood which had a fearsome kick to it's stride and could topple the best of men.. however I suspect they saw the insanity in keeping such a tipple so readily available to the masses. I've never tried the food at this place, but the views of the Thames are great and it's a nice pub to sit outside for a beer in the Summer. Staff seem a little cold and thus far that's what's held me back from venturing further with the food. Definitely worth a visit if you're out on a hot day though.

skrfuKrALwT2p7XqX4s9aQ.text: Interested to note that recently this hovel was fined by Greenwich Council for being well and truly filfthy. It is a great shame as the location (tourist trap) and building is of such historical importance!!! But, being that tourist trap, the owner (Frank the Yank), could not care less about his clientelbut just the money. An absolute disgrace that this place has been downhill for years. Dirty, poorly staffed and over priced.

TzqsoKDt2EC-oRduh2bxVQ.text: Beautiful view. TERRIBLE service. We were unsure how the restaurant worked (seat yourself or wait to be seated). We waited in the entrance area, looking admittedly tourist-y, and the bartender looked over at us before turning back to dishing out drinks. Five minutes later, we decided to approach the bar, because nothing else was working. It turns out that this is the appropriate way to order. Why the bartender did not beckon us over, I will never know. When you find a place to sit, you are expected to bring your utensils and napkins out to the tables yourself. The kids' lemonades were very small and heavy on the ice. While the burgers were tasty and juicy, there were bones in the fish that were the perfect size to choke on. There was a 12.5% gratuity that was automatically added to our bill. They did not earn it.

lZTm5p8hgPnPYInm9t5MnQ.text: The statue of Nelson, standing outside the Trafalgar Tavern facing the Thames, certainly attracted the attention of my well oiled American friends. Inside we found a fairly empty pub with plenty of traditional charm, and a fairly relaxed atmosphere. There is nothing particularly special about this place, save perhaps for its location, but on the other hand, there is not much wrong with it either.

AkNztw4QsBziKQCZYdsr-g.text: Is it just that Dickens did a tonne of boozing, or does it seem to anyone other than me that a surprising number of pubs in London claim to be this author's favourite haunt? The Trafalgar Tavern is another of Dickens' preferred waterfront watering holes, full of history and charm and located literally on the river. I have no quarrel with it, I quite like it in fact, but I am getting somewhat tired of hearing about Dickens loving one place or the other. Surely there were other thirsty writers in the London of old.

4sx0bFsqKkER26KLKqQ8Hw.text: This is one of my favourite pubs in London. Although it can be a bit pricey - this is Greenwich after all - I still keep coming back due to everything it has going for it. It is a beautiful pub along the river, decorated in dark, classic colours which lend to the sense of history one feels when inside. If you are lucky enough to snag a seat by the window, especially in the evening, you will be treated to a beautiful view of Canary Wharf. This is also a really nice pub to go to for drinks and food in the summer as there are plenty of tables outside, though as with the indoor window seats, you have to grab these spaces fast as they fill up quickly.

yID6YWno5jI01ZsueCDRvA.text: This has been one of my favorites when visiting London for years. We often just stop in for a pint. Outside by the river is perfect in the summer and inside by the fire is perfect in the winter. Every now and then we eat there as well. Typically something traditional like Fish & Chips. Great atmosphere, excellent beer, and the perfect location!

cBjCBCBLGkPr1zFSCNJJYg.text: Fabulous views, many draft beer choices and decent pub food. We dined in on the Scottish beef and an a classic cheeseburger.

photos.caption: Photo of Trafalgar Tavern - London, United Kingdom

9E5dtRd9LblySZpkz6tegg.text: Had a lovely walk along the Thames on a cold blustery day and ducked into this pub to warm up. We found a small table in front of the bar with a view of the river.  Traditional english fare was on the menu and a nice selection of beers on tap. The food was good but nothing to write home about.  Enjoyed the old photographs and artwork on the walls and learning anout the history.

XVa7sMqG6SusN6v461j9rQ.text: Great location but they just can't cope with crowds. Ordered a simple whitebait dish. 45 minutes and still counting. Manager disappeared saying he would sort it out and has run passed us with white bait dish. Not impressed now he's frigging around with ice. Still no show of food. We are leaving

LWGNutLEqeRxswNN2ko1zg.text: Great view and lots of seating in the bar area.  Many of the seats have a nice view so it's not stressful to find a place.  You can order from the full menu at the bar and the food was great.  Good beer selection. There were not a ton of vegetarian options but the ones we had were really good.  This place was recommended to us because of the view but the food was good too. There hot chocolate was good especially on a rainy day.

YDwPfDWtg-rwQ4R4vacRCQ.text: I love this pub. I used to come here all the time when I lived in the area. This is a charming pub sat along the river with incredible views of the water, canary wharf and North Greenwich. It's a brilliant place to have a Sunday pub lunch or just a few pints. Just to watch the boats float by!

JzxWpV8nrJiZFlO3yrEnaQ.text: This is a touristy place with a great view of the Thames by Cutty Sark. The first time I came here I didn't eat and just had some Pimm's but their English pub food, albeit touristy prices, are actually quitegood.The fish and chips is likely one of the best I've tried in London (though keep in mind I haven't tried many) and their fishcake was also delicious. Their jerk chicken sandwich just as good. If you are okay with paying over 12 GBP for pub food because of the view (should you be able to find seats outside or by the window) it's actually quite worth coming. Personally I would not want to pay 16 pounds for fish and chips but then again, if you're reading this, you're more likely a tourist than a student at Greenwich U, why not?

ln7UC1lzGAdZ2-V4h1a92w.text: Caveat that this is a review of the upstairs portion of what looks to be a pretty generic, if tourist-overrun pub. Regardless of the downstairs, the upstairs is an absolute gem.When my friends said their wedding reception was above a pub I was a bit dubious; imagining Only Fools and Horses style shenanigans, which did seem a little out of character. I shouldn't have worried about this, my first London-based wedding (I was so excited to get the tube to a wedding!) - this old Georgian townhouse's upstairs area is utterly beautiful and surprisingly large. Three separate areas - one cosy bar/reception area and two large dining rooms - made for a great reception setting and an even better dancefloor.The views were also pretty fabulous and there are balconies to pile out onto if vertigo isn't your thing. The sight across the river to the o2 is fabulous at night.Food was delicious and servers were all nice. This really was a special place to have an occasion - don't be put off by it's pub location!

-5kAzVToHfyXi-70oYGhqg.text: One of the worst places to go for any food in Greenwich. Seriously stay away! Had an argument with the barman because apparently soda water is the same as mineral water. Then the completely forgot 3 orders now bear in mind we asked about our food 3 times before with no one coming back to us the. Final straw is asking again on replacing cold Yorkshire puddings and being given roast potatoes. Stay away from this place it used to be a gem of a restaurant but the service is horrendous,the good is mediocre and quite frankly you leave here feeling extremely stressed its disgraceful!!!!!!!! Just an update The 3 missing dished came an hour and a half after the other 7 dishes. Lunch with the family ruined!

UWadZP1uPY9t5jsm1oNmvQ.text: Dined here for Sunday lunch. This is a beautiful pub restaurant in a lovely setting right on the river it has a well layed out restaurant and very nice friendly staff.The food was good, the roast beef was tasty not the best or worst I've had. They did forget my Yorkshire pudding and i had to ask for it and when it came it was very dry and bland. Im not a fan of cabbage on Sunday Roasts i dont feel it belongs, there are plenty of other vegetables that work better. So gotta drop marks for that.Its hard to find a truly amazing Sunday Roast there must be one out there in London, but here was not it but still a nice meal and enjoyable.

QYskseIn8QD_TheyKrAIdQ.text: Love me some pub food, and Trafalgar did not disappoint. This is a bit of a historic building which i love, and it is very quaint and charming. no fuss no muss decor.  the local people i interacted with were amazing! Menu was heavy on the fish side..but, well rounded featuring organic food so that alone gets a star. They also have a pub menu where you will find classic English pub fare like sausage and mash, fish and chips, etc.I had both.. both were grand!Decent price point, good service. I am about to become a regular, lol

WjhfP7SThgp4cj1U2N3gzg.text: A tale of two cities indeed.This is one of my locals. I frequented this place so often after my classes at University of Greenwich that my lecturers should've just held classes here. The Trafalgar (as us locals call it) is right along The Thames - perfect views and so close you even get splashed on summer days.Tale 1 -- The downstairs of the Trafalgar is a pub. Yup a pub...towards the back is a restaurant (never dined in that bit). It's alright as pubs go and they serve Boddington's which is always good in my books. The features downstairs are the window seats. People jockey for these seats like Louis Hamilton jockeys for pole position, so if you get one - milk it. The loos could definetly use some attention which is a shame and the food is nothing to write home about because...Tale 2 - is the star of this show. The upstairs is where they hold functions. Some years back I organised my company's Christmas Party here. Amazing. This is, after all, a Georgian building and the upstairs is a stunning affair. 3 rooms - The Ante Room which is a smaller bar and lounge, the room just off that which we used as the reception/congretating area and the main feature - dining room! Heigh ceilings, floor to ceiling windows to show The Thames River in all its glory. The lights at night really sparkle on the water - gorgeous. The room is only adorned with plush curtains that are always drawn back and a piano. It's also quite spacious, to say the least. I was able to use one end as the dining/seating area and the other as the dancing area. They also have bespoke catering on-site, so that really made it a win-win!Personally, I don't hang out here anymore because the pub is just a pub and far too crammed on the weekends with tourists but if you want something special or planning a wedding, stylish party of 100+ then the upstairs is for you.#LiveLifeLikeLDN

k123AOBPdUS4RV9Vp3jqeg.text: This was the first place we ate at when we arrived in London and this pub did not disappoint. It has a lot of out door seating and a beautiful view of the river. Everyone inside seem so friendly and I really like how you just walk up to the bar and order drinks and food at same time. First thing to try in London, of course, fish and chips and bangers and mash. I wish people knew how to make fish and chips here in the U.S. like they do here. It was light, flakey and crispy, not oily tasting at all. Sausage grilled perfectly and the mash was so creamy. Both dishes were super tasty!!!

1-rMC2D8oviw1gdUx_RaCA.text: Decided to dine in the restaurant at the rafalger with my wife, only 2 other people in the restaurant, it was a Monday however, quite busy outside though.View from restaurant really nice ovcross the Thames.Service by friendly American was best part of our visit, food left a lot to be desired!Whitebait overcooked, we both tried that my wife hhad a salad for main which was a bit of a "mish-mash" not well presented and dressing tasted synthetic, maybe out of a bottle! Would come back for location but not to eat!

4gq0MNqjvkAyvjnDGQK0qg.text: Epic pub. London is known for its pubs, its pub grub and most notably of this, its roasts. That fame is not always warranted and some very sorry pub grub is served up in establishments across our fair city. But not at The Trafalgar Tavern. For a Sunday party, I was summoned to Greenwich and had to whip out my GPS to find the place. Tucked behind the university, it has an amazing riverfront view. A huge pub, it stretches back from the big front room to the bar and a full restaurant. Fantastic selection of ciders and beers, and some festive mulled wine. The food was the high point for me, best fish and chips I've had in London. And relatively inexpensive. The roasts my friends ordered, from chicken to pork and beef looked incredible. These are roasts which have turned non-believers into devoted roast eaters. If it's a Sunday and you want a killer roast experience, a nice walk in a pretty place, this is the pub for you.

V0zB8-GP4Dtozl-jPGdPNA.text: Huge, famous pub on the river that might just be it's own worst enemy. It' gets suuuuuuper busy here, especially on sunny weekends. So you can expect a long wait at the bar, to be standing outside unless you get down there really early, and for the restaurant section to be fully booked.Mind you, it is on the river. It does offer lovely views and it is a great spot for getting your drinks in the sun.Lower your expectations and you'll enjoy. There aren't many riverside alternatives in the Greenwich area.

Qxw5h5odcBy1XXhNuNV7zA.text: Can't really add much to what has already been said about the Trafalgar Tavern. It's a fairly normal pub in an area steeped in history and architecture. What I will add is that the upstairs area, reserved for weddings and events is truly spectacular. I came here for a friend's wedding a fortnight ago and what an amazing main room there turned out to be tucked upstairs in this ancient pub. As you walk up the stairs there is a beautiful smaller room with huge bay windows, this leads to a smaller 'snug' bar which is truly cosy. The views from up here were simply stunning. Throw in a main room which has enough space for around 150 people plus dance floor space and it's a tidy little wedding venue.So, I did spend a bit of time downstairs whilst at the 'do'. But it seemed pretty mundane, lovely as it was. Anyhoo, the party was definitely going off upstairs and it's here where I believe this pub really, truly shines. If it's local to you, and you're about to get hitched, you'd be silly not to check out the facilities upstairs, they really are a pleasant surprise.

photos.caption: Photo of Trafalgar Tavern - London, United Kingdom. Upstairs private room. Suitable for wedding and events.

TLAbHLNFWkFGRRAKTSJQjg.text: First Sunday back and all I want is a proper Sunday Roast. On the suggestion of a very beautiful woman, some friends and I headed the The Trafalgar Tavern. The weather seemed to be cooperating, so a nice walk around Greenwich Park and the river lead us to this good sized, friendly tavern. Now the main event, the Roast. I got the beef, of course, and it was amazing. Possibly the best I've had in London. The meat was prepared perfectly, the potatoes, veggies and pudding were all a delight. They have a good selection of Sharp's beers, as well as a few other randoms, including Murphy's Stout. Definitely will be coming back here for a roast in the near future!

e6VH3XvKDNjjghzhb7xLjQ.text: Myself and a friend happened to be spending the evening sat at the bar on the Thames Clipper catamaran ferries when we first spied the Trafalgar. Zooming past on our way down the Thames, the pub looked spectacular when lit up at night and from the vantage point of the river. That's certainly saying something when you take into account its location, sandwiched beside some majestic Georgian architecture.Once inside, however, I couldn't help but feel slightly let down. The Trafalgar doesn't seem to be able to figure out what exactly it wants to be. It looks like a yacht club from the outside, and even inside, the layout seems strangely spartan, and more like the clubhouse of a distinguished old boys bar than a venue open to the public.All of the furniture is either vintage or doing a good impersonation of being vintage. Red leather lining abound. Having said that, the bar menu looked quite appealing and seemed good value. The place is evidently popular too, with a decent crowd for a midweek night.

photos.caption: Photo of Trafalgar Tavern - London, United Kingdom

NWFAvu_UXLU9VjpiWGDx7g.text: I got married here in the Trafalgar Club. The organisation and attention from the staff was excellent, all of my guests praised the food and we had a wonderful time. The dancefloor was a bit sweaty as it has limited ventilation but our guests never moved from it and everyone loved the view of the river. For a smaller sized or tier wedding it is an excellent venue assuming you have a red theme as the walls of the Club are bright red.

photos.caption: Photo of Trafalgar Tavern - London, United Kingdom
